Anabelle is already five years into her business. Her business is very important to her because it helps her in meeting the family’s expenditures. Anabelle wants to continue her business until her children finish their education. She is now asking for a loan of PHP15,000 that she needed for the improvement of her vending business.

loans.use: additional capital for her business

location.town: San Pedro San Pablo, Aurora, Isabela

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma M. is from the village of Manticao in Misamis Oriental. She is 37 years old. Elma is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Elma uses her trisikad, a bicycle-powered carriage, to provide transportation services to local community members. Elma has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately  PHP a month from these activities.

Elma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elma is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services that she provides. This will be Elma's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy supplies to expand her business

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio S. is a 52-year-old farmer from Sto Niño, South Cotabato. He manages a one-hectare rice field, which is just enough to support his family. The eldest of his four children is 21 years old. He started his rice farming business in 1988. Now he is confident that he can continue his business with the support of financial assistance to increase the size of his harvest.

He would like to request a loan of 8,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to sustain his farm. It would also be a big help for him in supporting his family.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Leila

texts.en:
Leila L., 42, is a farmer from Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She owns 1-hectare rice field and runs rice farming business. She's a mother of three children. Her eldest is 21 years old. She sends her children to school out from the income she receives from her farm.

She's now requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. worth 15,000 PHP. This is very helpful for her to buy supplies necessary for her farm. She will be able to save her financing from CEVI instead of lending money from rice trader which has a high interest.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Richelle

texts.en:
Richelle, 27 years of age, is married to  Ryan, a medical representative. The couple is blessed with 2 children, namely: Shaina Mae, 7 years of age and Grade 2 pupil, and Gwyneth Yvonne, 4 years old. The family presently residing Sto.Niño Subdivision, Cabaruan, Cauayan  City.

She operates a typical village store for almost 1 year already and her daily net income is PHP400.00. She wanted to avail a loan amounting to PHP15,000.00 to purchase some additional grocery items to sell in her retail store. She wants to secure the education of her two kids, that's why she spends her money wisely and she value even small things. She believes that patience is her key to a bountiful and productive business. She is thankful to those people who support her all the way.

loans.use: Additional capital in her business

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
"Amahong", a local name for clams, and fish vending is the business activity of Riza M., 28 years old, married to Mr. Ronald M.. Both are residents of Purok-4 Pangabuan, Tangub City. As a couple, they have 5 children who are now school-age and one infant. Riza has been engaged in 'amahong' and fish vending for 14 years already which gives her an average net income of P 3,500 per month. Her income helps her husband in supporting their family. Her husband is also a fish vendor.

Since their children are now growing and the needs of their family have increased nowadays, Riza can’t help but find a way to meet the needs of their family. As a good member of PAGLAUM MPC under the PDP-LP Program, she is given the privilege of accessing her 3rd loan in the amount of P 5,500. She is very thankful to PMPC for the trust given her. She enjoys the other products and services offered to all the members of PAGLAUM MPC. The proceeds of this loan will be added to her capital for 'amahong' and fish vending and for buying materials for the renovation of their house.

loans.use: Additional capital for 'amahong' and fish vending and the purchase of housing materials

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith L., 34 years old, is a pig grower. She has three children. Her eldest child is only eight years old and is currently going to school. She has been very busy thinking of expanding her business. Currently, she has three pigs, which she nurtures well so that she will be able to sell them at a higher cost.

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy feed and hog supplements to grow her pigs and sustain her business.

loans.use: business capital

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda I.'s ambition in life is to be successful in her business. She currently engaged in hog raising. The pigs, which she raises for four months, are what constantly provide her family an income to buy an adequate supply of food and other basic needs. She has 12 children. Her eldest child is 36 years old and no longer lives with them. Now, she is doing the best she can to raise enough money to support her big family.

She is asking a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy feed and hog supplements to help grow her pigs bigger and bolder.

loans.use: additional business capital

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is 44 years old. She is engaged in a food vending business in their village. Since her income is not sufficient, she decided to look for another source of income so she now also an AVON dealer. She earns 25% from any products that she purchases. She is trying her best to cover her family’s expenses. She has a child in college, and one is presently in elementary education.

Sonia's husband died a few months ago. She has to double her time and needs to work hard. Sonia needs additional capital in order to continue operating her business as her source of income. Her income in her business serves her to assist in covering her family’s living costs. She wants to borrow the amount of PHP 7,000 as additional capital for her business.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

location.town: San Pedro, San Pablo, aurora, Isabela

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị's Group

texts.en:
T. Nguyễn Thị (10117100013) is a 24-year-old woman who lives in the town of Đông Anh - Hà nội. T. is the leader of a 6-member loan group sponsored by SEDA. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Xóm Hậu 1 (2).


T. is married and has one young child. To making a living, T. operates a family member's poultry business, where she raises and sells chickens. T. has been engaged in this business for over a year and earns approximately 2.000.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2008, T. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2.204.000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase chicks to raise and sell in the future. She is now requesting a new loan of 654.000 VND which that she will use to buy more chicks. This will be T.'s third loan from SEDA. T. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1. Hoàng Thị T. (10117100011) is a 54-year-old woman who is requesting a 3.270.000 VND loan to support her food stall.


2. Trần Thị Quý (10117100006) is a 43-year-old woman who is requesting a 7.194.000 VND loan to support her business making & selling food.


3. Nguyễn Thị N. (10117100010) is a 52-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.450.000 VND loan to support her food stall.


4. Vũ Thị Quá (10117100005) is a 63-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.450.000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store.


5. Nguyễn Thị S. (10117100017) is a 51-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.322.000 VND loan to support her clothing business.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


T. Nguyễn Thị (10117100013) là 24 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Đông Anh - Hà nội.  T. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Xóm Hậu 1 (2).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán.  T. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 1 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, T. kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND.  Vào 2008, T. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  T. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 2.204.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 0,654 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Hoàng Thị T. (10117100011) là 54 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3.270.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


2.  Trần Thị Quý (10117100006) là 43 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.194.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


3.  Nguyễn Thị N. (10117100010) là 52 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.450.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


4.  Vũ Thị Quá (10117100005) là 63 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.450.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


5.  Nguyễn Thị S. (10117100017) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.322.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh quần áo.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Atto

texts.en:
Atto E. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell. Atto is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a mechanic. She has 3 children and 2 attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar and pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane P., 37 years old, owns and manages a small piggery. She has one sow and four small pigs. The sow produces piglets, which she also sells for income. She grows four other pigs and sells them after four months. The income she makes from having a piggery is what she uses to buy her family all the basic things they need.

Mary Jane wants to grow her livelihood more. She would like to request a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional piglets and pig feed.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en:
Natividad is an industrious mother and wife.  One of her guiding principles is "patience is the key to success and productivity."  She manages a hog-raising livestock business.  When she sells a hog, her net income is PHP2,000.00.   Natividad wants a loan of PHP5,000.00 to purchase some hog feed, and some hogs to raise.  She needs a lot of encouragement to pursue her business in productive way. She is grateful to those people who supported her in financial aspects, especially to her children. 

Natividad is married to Juan Sr and they have ten children: Rosemarie, 39, elementary; Anabelle, 36, a midwife; Juan Jr., 34, a college graduate; Cynthia, 32; Ceasar, 30; Rosita, 27, a recording artist for almost 1 year; Rowena, 26, a nursing student; Josephine, 23, a criminology student; Marites, 21, at college level; and their youngest is Reylon,17, who is a college student. Natividad and her husband peacefully reside in the village of Nungnungan, Cauayan City, a semi-urban area, and their house is located along the highway. She said that she's happy with what she has right now, because she feels a lot of contentment in her life.

loans.use: To purchase feed and additional piglets.

loans.name: Peter Njunguna

texts.en:
Peter is 48 years old. He is married with two children. He owns a general store in Kikuyu Town. His other sources of income are the rental homes he owns.  

Peter has never taken a loan with a local bank. He was introduced to KADET by one his borrower group members.  Most of his customers are from Kikuyu Town. He wants to use the loan to add inventory to his general store. He hopes to expand his business by being a soda distributor, and one day, he would like to build more rental houses.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add inventory

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa L., 51, is a rice farmer and a hog raising business owner in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato Minadanao.  She has been helping her husband till their farm to be able to have an abundant harvest. Aside from rice, she also raises pigs. The piggery and farm are what she hopes will provide her with enough income to buy an adequate supply of food, clothes and other basic needs. 

She needs additional capital to grow her business. The loan will help buy the farming necessities as well as the additional piglets and feed for her small piggery.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Ainura's Group

texts.en:
Ainura is the leader of this group. She is thirty-eight years. She has three children. Her eldest son is nineteen and he works as a security guard. Her middle son, who is fifteen, goes to high school. The little daughter is five. 

Ainura and her husband do their best and work hard to support the family. While Ainura’s husband is engaged in farming, Ainura trades in newspapers, magazines and some other minutiae in a small shop. It took Ainura some effort and time until she and her husband were able to save 120$ to purchasing the goods and lease a kiosk.

Nevertheless, their efforts were justified. Ainura’s monthly income is around 325$. She is very enthusiastic about her business, which she started a year ago. Due to her entrepreneurial skills and diligence, she has made permanent customers. Ainura does not want to stop at this. She is full of energy and desires to go forward. She hopes that she will get a loan and be able to purchase soap, detergent, costume jewelry, and women’s underwear. She believes that these selling these goods will attract new customers and increase her turnover. Because winter is approaching, she is preparing to purchase coal and insulate her shop.

Ainura has three partners, Ainura, Dinara and Zalina.

Ainura, age 38, is the mother of five children. Her husband transports goods on his own truck. Ainura farms and sells milk. Ainura decided to apply for this loan to buy fuel for sowing and two tons of coal. 

Dinara, age 29, has three children. Her husband works in police security department. Dinara is a hairdresser. Her monthly income is around 90$. She needs a loan to buy a heater and linoleum for her salon. 

Zalina, age 24, has two children. Her husband looks after the household. Zalina sells women’s underwear. She goes to companies and sells her wares on the spot. She is able to sell more underwear this. She needs a loan to purchase underwear. With the rest of the loan she wants to buy a calf.

loans.use: To buy items for shop so she can insulate her shop and to purchase winter coal

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth E., 45 years old, is a rice farmer. She is also a pig grower in their village and currently raises four pigs. She has been able to earn income from her small farm and piggery that she uses to buy her family's food, clothing and other basic needs.

Janeth would like to apply for a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm and to buy the farming necessities. The loan will also help a lot in buying additional piglets and pig feed.

loans.use: To use for farm financing plus additional piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Baby Jane

texts.en:
Mrs. Baby Jane C., 42 years old, is a resident of Purok 4 Maquilao, Tangub City. She is married to Mr. Marcelo C. who works as a casual contractor at Cagayan de Oro City. She is blessed with two children aged 12 and 17 years old.

Baby Jane is engaged in the direct selling of Avon products and longganisa (sausages flavoured with indigenous spices) and has been in this business for four years. She is able to earn a minimum of P4,000 per month from these business activities.

Considering that Baby Jane has two children, her husband’s salary is not enough to support the needs of their family, especially in raising their children. That’s why she engaged in dealing Avon products and longganisa to help her husband.

As a good member of Paglaum MPC under the PDP-LP Program (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People), Baby Jane is given the privilege of obtaining her 7th loan of P4,000. She is very thankful to PMPC for the trust given to her. She also expresses her pleasure of being a member of Paglaum MPC because she can obtain the products and services offered by the Coop to all its members.

The proceeds of this loan will be added to Baby Jane’s capital and the income will be used for their daily needs and in repaying her loan.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana is 39 years old.  She is engaged in selling snack foods like "banana cue" (fried bananas on barbecue sticks).  She sells in their village in Nagassican. She is selling them house to house to earn bigger income to meet the needs of her family.  She is married to Elpidio Sr., who is a government employee; and they have three loving children: Lovely-14 years old who is a high school student; Elpidio Jr.-11 years old, an elementary pupil and Daisy May -- an eight-year old elementary pupil.

Susana and Elpidio hope that they would be able to continue support the schooling of their three children. In this regard, they strive hard to meet the basic needs of the family. Susana says that time is gold and because of this she keeps herself busy vending her goods. She would like to apply a loan amounting PHP5,000. She hopes for the approval of her requested loan.

loans.use: Additional capital for banana cue vending business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita J., 63, is the mother of six children. She lives in Norala, South Cotabato. She has been managing a rice farming business since 1989.  The income received from the farm is enough to sustain her family. She would like to request a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. worth 15,000 PHP.  With the help of microfinance, she will be able to purchase supplies needed for her business and have a good harvest.

loans.use: To purchase farming supplies

loans.name: Joseph Kaguru

texts.en:
Joseph is 36 years old and married with two children. He has been keeping chickens for about 12 years now and sells broilers (chickens for meat) to his customers in Kikuyu town, Limuru and at the Nderi shopping center.  

He formed his borrower group. He has never borrowed from another MFI and plans to use the loan to expand his chicken pen and buy more chickens for sale. He hopes to raise, and, one day supply, chickens in large quantities of over 2,000 (right now he supplies 200).

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more chicken (for meat) and expand his chicken pen

loans.name: Ayoo

texts.en:
Ayoo Santa sells flour, beans and dried fish, and is requesting a loan to purchase shorgum and more fish to sell. Ayoo is 32 years old and is married to a policeman. She has five children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase food for resale

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario A. is 48 years old and lives in Norala, South Cotabato. Rosario's rice farming business is a great help to provide for the basic needs of her family. The eldest of her four children is 22 years old. The income she receives from her farm sends her children to school.

She is now requesting financial assistance from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in the amount of 12,000 PHP.  This loan is enough to have farm supplies available for her farm with a lower interest rate charge.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria A. manages a rice farming business. She owns a 1-hectare rice field in Norala, South Cotabato.  She sustains her family through the income she receives from her farm.  She has four children; her eldest is 29 years old.

She is now requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in the amount of 15,000 PHP.  It will be very helpful to finance her business with a low interest rate. She will be able to send her children to school.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna sells "chicharon" (dried pork skin)  in their village.  She is already a widow and left to care for an eight-year old son named Mark, an elementary student.  Lorna would like to avail a loan PHP5,000 to expand her business so she can earn income which will allow her to buy additional educational materials for her child who is studying. She hopes that she could avail of the loan amount she is requesting.

Lorna is hoping that she could sustain the needs of her child. Through her business she could improve their way of living.

loans.use: Additional capital for business

loans.name: Shahzi Group

texts.en: Shahzi is the leader of the Shahzi Group. There are three members in this group and each of them wants a loan to expand and improve their business. They have requested a group of loan 42000 Afghani. Shahzi wants a loan to buy a new sewing machine for her tailoring business. Laitifa's husband and Banazer's brother want a loan for their fresh fruit shop. They are very happy about the loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Simon Gathungu

texts.en:
Simon, 32, is a married father of one child. He owns a general store and also supplies milk and charcoal to retailers. He has been in the business for a period of about five years. He earns a profit of approximately 19,000 kenya shillings a month.

He was introduced to KADET by a friend who is an existing KADET client. He wants to use the loan to buy more charcoal to supply to retailers and also add more inventory to his general store. He hopes to be a major supplier of charcoal and expand his general store.


About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell to retailers and to add inventory to his general store

loans.name: John Mwangi

texts.en:
John, 41, is married to Joyce and has three children. John was introduced to Kiva partner Kadet through an existing client. He is applying for his first loan with Kadet. He has been operating a tailoring and dressmaking shop for the past 11 years. He also does small scale farming as another source of income. John intends to purchase more sewing machines for his business with this loan.

His hopes and dreams are to open a big clothing shop and stock a variety of materials which can attract more buyers. He describes himself as a hardworking business man.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more sewing machines for his tailoring business

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 37 years old, married to Beth Wambui, and they have four school-going children. James has been operating his motorcycle transportation business in Naivasha town for the past year. James was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He intends to buy a new motorcycle with the money from the loan and employ someone else to operate it for him as a taxi. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle for his transport business

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson is 35 years old, married to Loise Wanjiru, and they have two school-going children. Nelson has been selling clothes in Naivasha town for the last four years which has been the main source of income for his family.

Nelson was introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his first loan and he plans to use it to purchase shoes to sell. He hopes this will increase his income.

Nelson hopes to see his business grow into a big boutique one day.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy shoes to sell to his customers

loans.name: Purity

texts.en: Purity has operated her spare-parts shop in Naivasha town for the last nine years. She is widowed, and all her three children have cleared school and are working. Purity was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her second loan. She repaid the first loan well which she used to buy more spare parts to sell. She plans to use this loan, also, to restock her business. Purity’s future dream is to expand her business and also to sell the spare parts on a wholesale level. She one day hopes to invest in the transport business by buying her own lorry (truck) which will be used to ferry goods (especially food products) to and from the market. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more spare parts to stock in her shop

loans.name: Cathérine

texts.fr: F. Cathérine est née en 1971 à Adjohoun dans le Département de l'Ouémé. Cathérine est mariée à DADJA Félix. Le couple a deux enfants tous scolarisés mais, ces enfants ne sont plus à sa charge. La famille vit depuis onze ans à Agbodjèdo à Cotonou, Capitale économique du Bénin. Cathérine et son mari assurent ensemble les charges de la famille. C'est les produits vivriers(maïs, mil, sorgho, riz, etc.) que Cathérine vend. Cathérine achète ces produits à Kpodji et les vend à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. Cathérine a déjà eu trois crédits de ALIDé qu'elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Toujours dans le souci de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle Cathérine sollicite ce quatrième crédit de ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Catherine F. was born in 1971 in Adjohoun of the Ouémé region. Catherine is married to Feliz Dadja. The couple have two children, both have been schooled, but they are no longer in their care. For the past eleven years, the family has lived in Agbodjedo, Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Catherine and her husband both contribute to the well-being of their family. Catherine sells food products such as corn, millet, sorghum, rice, etc. Catherine purchases her products in Kpodji and she resells in Dantokpa, the large international market of Benin. Catherine has had three previous loans with Alide (Kiva Field Partner) and she has repaid them all. With them she has been able to improve her business. Always with the goal of meeting client demands, Catherine is requesting a fourth loan from Alide, to supplement her working capital funds.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 100kg sacks of corn.

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
L. Nguyễn Thị (20201050010) is a 39-year-old woman who lives in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. L. is the leader of a 6-member L. group sponsored by SEDA. Although each member of the group receives an individual L., they are all responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Phú Mẫn 1 (2).


L. is widowed and has 3 school-aged children. To making a living, L. owns and operates a butcher shop where she prepares and sells pork in the local community. L. has been engaged in this business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3.600.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2007, L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. L. has successfully repaid a previous L. of 3.894.000 VND from SEDA. This previous L. was used to purchase additional products to sell. She is now requesting a new L. of 6.048.000 VND which will be used to purchase a transport vehicle to improve her business. This will be L.'s 5th L. from SEDA. L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1. Lê Thị B. (20201050011) is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 4.256.000 VND L. to support her livestock business.


2. Nguyễn Thị N. (20201050012) is a 45-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND L. to support her specialized retail store.


3. Nguyễn Thị T. (20201050013) is a 44-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND L. to support her furniture-making business.


4. Nghiêm Thị P. (20201050014) is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 4.704.000 VND L. to support her livestock business.


5. Nguyễn Thị L.  (20201050022) is a 53-year-old woman who is requesting a 4.256.000 VND L. to support her her furniture-making business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this L. was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


L. Nguyễn Thị (20201050010) là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  L. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Phú Mẫn 1 (2).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ giết mổ & bán T.t heo trong cộng đồng địa phương.  L. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 7 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, L. kiếm được khoảng 3.600.000 VND.  Vào 2007, L. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  L. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.894.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.048.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Lê Thị B. (20201050011) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.256.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Nguyễn Thị N. (20201050012) là 45 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


3.  Nguyễn Thị T. (20201050013) là 44 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.


4.  Nghiêm Thị P. (20201050014) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.704.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


5.  Nguyễn Thị L.  (20201050022) là 53 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.256.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: To purchase a transport vehicle for her butcher shop

loans.name: Gabriel Mambo

texts.en:
Gabriel is 52 years old and is married to Elizabeth. They are blessed with five daughters and one son.

Gabriel was introduced to Kiva partner KADET through an existing client. He is applying for his first loan with KADET. 

Gabriel has been operating a transport business as a taxi driver for the past two years. He wants to use this loan to purchase a car for his business. He also earns extra income from his rental houses.

Gabriel’s hope and dream is to purchase more cars for renting. He describes himself as an ambitious and a visionary businessman.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website:  www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a car for his taxi business

loans.name: John Macharia

texts.en:
John is a 25-year-old single man who sells women's clothing in the Kangemi market. He has been in the business for four years with a profit of approximately 25,000 Kenyan shillings a month. He wants to use the loan to buy more stock of clothes.

John has never borrowed a loan from any financial institution before. He was introduced to KADET by one of the borrower group members. John hopes to expand his business by adding more stock and also venturing into selling new clothes (instead of second-hand clothing).


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website:  www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more stock of used-clothing to his business

loans.name: Albino

texts.en: Albino S. is currently in the business of selling at her shop: tomatoes, phaste (groundnuts/peanuts or simsim/sesame seeds that have been ground or crushed into a paste), bags of salt, and bags of curry powder for vegetables. Albino is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has seven children and out of these children, only three go to school. Albino is requesting a loan to purchase bags of sugar and cooking oil to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of sugar and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Abraham

texts.en:
Abraham is 37 years old and is married to Mary Wanjiru. They have 4 school-going children. He has run his small retail business in Naivasha town for the past year.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy more retail products to sell in his shop in order to boost business and draw in more customers. He hopes to enter the transport business some day and buy his own cab to increase his income.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more retail products to sell in his shop

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en: Tamara S. lives in Sevan with her son, daughter-in-law and granddaughter. Tamara has been working in a laundry about 16 years. Three years ago, she opened her own food shop. Now, Tamara wants to sell household goods in her shop, so she is asking for $1.200 loan. With the future income from her loan, she intends to install a heating system in her house.

loans.use: To sell household goods in her shop

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is a 37-year-old single mother of two teenage children. She has been hawking (selling door-to-door) shoes along the streets of the slums of Mathare for four years. She is requesting a loan of Kes. 20,000 to purchase more shoes and sandals to sell. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and import her own wares. She describes herself as ambitious and hardworking and says that, since becoming a member of Faulu, she has begun keeping records.

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to sell

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is 41 years old.  She is engaged in snack vending business and also helps her husband in managing their furniture shop business.  She would like to develop and improve her business by having enough capital from the KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5,000 in order than she can earn more  to provide the needs of her family. Currently, she is spending on allowances, tuition fees and projects to her three children: Angeline-17 years old who is college student; Angelo-11 years old elementary pupil and Alexander Jr.-6 years old.

Virginia is married to Alexander Sr. who is making products such as:  cabinet,chair and other kinds of furniture. They are able to generate PHP5000 weekly but then, they still need to double the income to meet then needs of their children. She is hoping that through the support of the lenders, all her business goals will be achieved.

loans.use: Additional capital for business development

loans.name: Hayridin

texts.ru: Хайридин Убайдов проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 37 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Хайридин по специальности "шофер". Он более 10 лет занимается перевозками грузов. У имеется грузовая автомашина "КАМАЗ", на котором установлен деревянный контейнер. Кредит просит для установки железного контейнера, т.к. с ним можно работать в любое время суток.
texts.en:
Hayridin U. lives in the city of Vahdat. He is 37 years old, married and has 6 children. Hayridin is a driver by trade. He has been involved in freight transportation for over 10 years. He has a KAMAZ truck with a wooden container installed. He is requesting a loan in order to install a metal container, so that he can utilize it for work at any time of day.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Installation of metal container

loans.name: Viviane

texts.fr: A. Viviane est née en 1982 à Cotonou, Capitale économique du Bénin. Viviane est mariée à CHAFFA Gilles. Le couple a deux enfants encore à sa charge. La famille vit depuis trois ans à Kowegbo à Cotonou. Viviane et son mari assurent ensemble les charges de la famille. Viviane est allée à l'école jusqu'au secondaire mais elle a finalement abandonné les études au profit du commerce. Ainsi, depuis trois ans Viviane vend des tissus, vêtements, jeans, mèches de coiffure, amuses-gueule, etc. C'est dans sa boutique sise à son domicile que Viviane vend ses produits. Mais Viviane achète ses produits tantôt à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, tantôt à Lomé, Capitale du Togo, pays voisin du Bénin. Viviane a besoin de plus de moyens financiers qu'elle en a pour mieux développer sa boutique. C'est pourquoi, Viviane sollicite un prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Viviane A. was born in 1982 at Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Viviane is married with Gilles Chaffa. The couple have two children, both are still in their care. For the past three years the family has lived in the Kowegbo district of Cotonou. Viviane and her husband share the family responsibilities. Viviane attended school up until high school but then she stopped to start up her business. For the past three years Viviane has been selling fabrics, clothings, jeans, hair products, and snacks etc. Viviane sells her products from a boutique located in her home. Viviane purchases her products in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and also in Lome, the capital city of Togo, a neighboring country of Benin. Viviane requires financial resources to better develop her boutique. That is why she is requesting a loan from Alide (Kiva Field Partner).


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fabrics, jeans, hair product, snacks, etc.

loans.name: Adela

texts.en:
Adela M. is from the village of Poblacion Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 57 years old. Adela is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Adela owns and operates a tailoring business where she providers alterations and tailoring services to local community members. Adela has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Adela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adela is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This will be Adela's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en:
Mathew is a 38 year-old married father of two daughters, Lucy and Ruth. He describes himself as a stable businessman. He has run Mugunda Fabricators since 1996, providing fabrication of metal products, such as doors, windows, chairs, and tables. He also earns income from his retail shop and employs two people. He is requesting a loan of Kes. 50,000 to rent a new modern workspace for his business. 

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To rent a new workspace for his business

loans.name: Ermy

texts.en:
Ermy is already a widow.  Her three children are already married but she still help her children to meet their needs.  

Ermy is a food snack vendor in their village in Nagassican, Santiago City. Due to the demands of her customers, she needs to have additional capital to be used for the maintenance of her business.  She is now asking for financial support from the KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5,000.  She believes that this amount will be of great help for her to purchase different commodities she needed.

loans.use: Additional capital for vending activity

loans.name: Mohbigul

texts.ru: Мохбигул Давлатова проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 40 лет. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Она имеет собственный магазин, в котором более 12 лет занимается торговлей. Она в основном торгует игрушками. Муж работает таксистом. Кредит просит для увеличения товараооборота.
texts.en:
Mohbigul D. lives in the city of Vahdat. She is 40 years old, married and has 3 children. She owns a store where she has been involved in retail sales for over 12 years. She primarily sells toys. Her husband works as a taxi driver. Mohbigul is requesting a loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Rakarya

texts.en:
Rakarya N. sells beer from her home. She is requesting a loan to purchase more beer to sell. Rakarya is a 40-year-old woman who is widowed. She is the mother of 7children, all of whom go to school.With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees of her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more beer to sell

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is a loving mother of four children. She is from the village of San Pedro San Pablo, Aurora, Isabela. Her husband, named Leopoldo, is a family driver. Lolita is 53 years old and engaged in direct selling business of AVON cosmetic products and tending a "sari-sari" store (community based store).  She has been in this business for three years.  Some of her children are studying and she hopes that they finish their studies.  

Since her income is insufficient, she would like to borrow a loan of PHP15,000 from the KIVA lenders.  This amount will assist her in making her business grow and profitable.

loans.use: additional capital for her business

location.town: San Pedro San Pablo, Aurora, Isabela

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
"Achieving success in life needs sacrifice and humility," says Rosalina. She is 57 years old who is married to Quirino Antonio.  They are blessed with five children but all of them are married already. 

Rosalina is selling native cakes in their village. She said that she is able to earn PHP3,000 a month. Improving her business is what she dreams so that she could earn bigger capital for her family needs. She would like to ask financial support to the KIVA lenders amounting PHP5,000. This amount she request will serve a big help most especially to make her business a productive one.She hopes that she could obtain the loan amount she is requesting.

loans.use: Additional capital for rice cakes vending business

loans.name: Firmine

texts.fr: H. Firmine est née en 1975 à Abomey, ville historique du Bénin. Firmine réside avec sa famille depuis une vingtaine d'année au quartier Missèbo à Cotonou capitale économique du Bénin. Firmine est mariée à TIDJANI Soulé, un chauffeur, et est mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés. Firmine vient en aide à son mari Soulé dans les charges de la famille grâce au revenu de son activité. En effet,Firmine vend des sacs de sortie et des tissus au grand marché missèbo de Cotonou. Firmine achète ses produits à Lomé, Capitale du Togo, pays voisin du Bénin. Pour répondre à la forte demande de sa clientèle pendant cette période de fête de fin d'année, Firmine sollicite un prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Firmine H. was born in 1975 in Abomey, a historic town of Bénin. For about twenty years, Firmine has been living with her family in the neighborhood Missèbo in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Firmine is married to Soulé TIDJANI, a driver, and is the mother of three children all in school.

Thanks to the income from her activity, Firmine is able to help her husband with the family’s expenses. Indeed, Firmine sells purses and fabric at the large Missèbo market in Cotonou. Firmine buys her products from Lomé, the capital of Togo – a neighboring country of Bénin. To meet the high demand of her customers during the year-end holidays, Firmine is requesting a loan from ALIDé.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of purses and fabric.

loans.name: Shuname

texts.en: Shuname is the 27-year-old mother of one nine-year-old boy. She sells secondhand clothes in Nairobi. She has been running this business for five years and hopes to diversify into other lines of business. Shuname is requesting a fourth loan of Kes 80,000 to add stock of secondhand clothes to her business. She describes herself as successful and says that her business has grown since joining Faulu Kenya. About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add to her stock of used clothes

loans.name: Bibihursand

texts.ru: Бибихурсанд Холова проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 45 лет. Вдова, имеет 4 детей. Бибихурсанд более 15 лет занимается торговлей. Она имеет магазин в котором торгует хозяйственными товарами. Ей также помогают ее дети. Кредит просит для закупа нового ассортимента.
texts.en:
Bibihursand H. lives in the city of Vahdat. She is 45 years old, a widow and has 4 children. Bibihursand has been involved in retail sales for over 15 years. She owns a store where she sells household goods. Her children also help her. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase a new selection of goods.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of new goods selection

loans.name: Tô's Group

texts.en:
Nụ Tô Thị (20213010019) is a 38-year-old woman who lives in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. Nụ is the leader of a 5-member loan group sponsored by SEDA. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is An Ninh 1 (5).


Nụ is married and has 4 school-aged children. To making a living, Nụ owns and operates a recycling business where she hauls away plastics and other recyclables for local businesses and community members. Nụ has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3.500.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2007, Nụ joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nụ has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.256.000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase additional scrap metal to sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 6.048.000 VND that she will use to purchase additional scrap metal to sell. This will be Nụ's third loan from SEDA. Nụ plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her immediate family members.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1. Nguyễn Thị H. (20213010016) is a 35-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her service-based business.


2. Vũ Thị H. (20213010017) is a 46-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food.


3. Đào Thị Thư (20213010018) is a 47-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her livestock business.


4. Nguyễn Thị L. (20213010021) is a 33-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her clothing business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Nụ Tô Thị (20213010019) là 38 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Nụ là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là An Ninh 1 (5).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chuyên chở các sản phẩm có thể tái chế bằng nhựa hay các sản phẩm có thể tái chế khác cho các doanh nghiệp và người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Nụ thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Nụ kiếm được khoảng 3.500.000 VND.  Vào 2007, Nụ đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Nụ đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.256.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua phế liệu bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.048.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nguyễn Thị H. (20213010016) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


2.  Vũ Thị H. (20213010017) là 46 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


3.  Đào Thị Thư (20213010018) là 47 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Nguyễn Thị L. (20213010021) là 33 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh quần áo.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: To purchase additional scrap metal to sell

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita is 38 years old who is married to Jesus. The couple is blessed with three children: Jay Anne-7 years old elementary pupil; Jamica-5 years old and Johucent-4 years old. Her family is living happily in the village of Calao East, Santiago City. 

Clarita is a direct seller of cosmetic products in their village.  She would like to buy more products so that she could earn a higher income.  In this regard, she is asking for a loan capital from the KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5,000.  This is of really great help in purchasing different products that will result to income increase.

loans.use: Additional capital for business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dancun

texts.en:
Dancun is a 30 year-old married father of two boys. Dancun runs a woodwork and electronics shop in the Mathare slums of Nairobi. He has been in this business for six years and employs two people. He is requesting a loan for Kes. 20,000 to purchase more timber and electronic items. He describes himself as “determined to succeed” and says that since he became a member of Faulu he has become a better at saving his profits. In the future, he hopes to have a sustainable business that requires no loans and hopes also to expand his business into the building of houses.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add supplies of timber & electronic items

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en:
Vicente is engaged in rice farming business. He is married to Ma. Elena who is working as an Overseas Filipino Worker (OFW).  They have two children: Dhaphni, a 13-year old high school student and Hyacinth, 12-year old high school student.

Vicente and Ma. Elena hopes that they could continue to support the schooling of their children. He said that he needs to develop his farming business. He said that his income is not enough so he is asking for additional capital amounting to PHP15,000. This will be used to purchase farm inputs and other necessary farming needs.

loans.use: Additional capital for rice farming business

loans.name: Susma

texts.en:
Mrs. Susma S. lives in Tangal. Tangal is located in Lalitpur district and is one of the busier suburbs of lalitpur. Most of the people in this region are engaged in handicraft work.  Susma lives with her husband and one son. Her husband Manoj S. works in his own hardware store and her son is studying in grade 9.

Mrs. S. opens her cosmetic shop 3 years ago. She wants to add a variety of personal care products to her shop because the demand is constantly increasing. Due to their financial condition, however, she cannot invest more in her business. So she is requesting for Rs 25,000.00 loans to buys more supplies of cosmetics for her shop.

loans.use: to invest in more supplies of cosmetics for her shop

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is a 26 year old business lady. She runs a boutique in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. She has been in this business for four years. She also earns extra income through farming. She is requesting for a loan of Kes. 20,000 to buy supplies of trousers to sell. A mother to one child, Edith hopes to become a clothes wholesaler. She describes herself as hardworking. 

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy supplies of  trousers for resale

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en: Mrs. Beverly A. is a very industrious mother of 5 children. She is 37 years old and a resident of P3 Minsubong, Tangub City. She is married to Mr. Eugenio A., a laborer with an average income of P200.00 a day. The income of her husband is not enough to support her 4 dependent children especially with their school needs. To help her husband, she decided to engage in the business of selling bananas, firewood and other products. With an initial capital of P1,000.00 for bananas and P200.00 for firewood, she has been able to sustain her business for 10 years. Presently she is earning an average net income of P3,500.00 a month which is a great help with supporting her family. With excellent character and loyalty in our co-op, she has been able to avail her 2nd cycle loan under the PDP-LP Program in the amount of P10,000.00. This will add to her capital for bananas and firewood. Her future plans are to repair her house and be able to continually support her children, especially for their college education.

loans.use: Additional capital for bananas and firewood for resale

loans.name: Janette

texts.en:
Janette G. is from the village of Upper Dicayas. She is 39 years old. Janette is married. To make a living, Janette owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing carpentry services by her husband to the local community. Janette has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Janette joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janette has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. Janette is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase construction materials needed to repair their house. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Janette from PMPC. She plans to improve their house to live in. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase constuction materials for house repair

loans.name: Honorine

texts.fr: W. Honorine est née en 1977 à Abomey, dans le Département du ZOU. Honorine est mariée à FATAÏ Omiyaley, un tailleur. Le couple a trois enfants encore à sa charge. La famille vit depuis sept ans à Agbodjèdo à Cotonou. C'est ensemble avec son mari que Honorine assurent les charges de la famille. Honorine vend des habits de façon ambulante. Honorine achète ses habits à Lomé, Capitale du Togo, pays voisin du Bénin. Honorine veut mieux développer son activité afin de répondre efficacement à la demande de sa clientèle. C'est pourquoi Honorine sollicite un prêt de ALIDé pour y arriver.
texts.en:
Honorine W. was born in 1977 in Abomey, in the county of Zou. Honorine is married to Omiyaley FATAÏ, a tailor. The couple is still financially responsible for three children. For the last seven years, the family has been living in Agbodjèdo in Cotonou. Together with her husband, Honorine provides for the family.

Honorine sells clothing door to door. Honorine buys her clothing in Lomé, the capital of Togo, a neighboring country of Bénin. Honorine wants to better develop her business in order to efficiently meet the demand of her customers. For this reason and in order to succeed, Honorine is requesting a loan from ALIDé.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothing.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 32 year old businessman who runs a vehicle spares shop in the Kariokor area of Nairobi. He also offers vehicle mechanic services. John has been in this business since 2002. He is requesting for a loan of Kes. 20,000 to add to his stock of spare parts for sale. He describes himself as hardworking and committed and hopes to be a successful business person one day. He says that he has learned business management skills since joining Faulu Kenya Ltd.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add supplies of spare parts

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en: Mrs. Anecita M., 33 years of age, is an active member of the PDP-LP Program of PAGLAUM MPC. She is a resident of P5 Garang, Tangub City. Anecita is married to Mr. Larry M. and they have been blessed with 7 children. Her husband is a fisherman with an average income of only P100.00 a day. With this situation, it is hard for them to support the family. She decided to engage in business in order to help her husband in meeting the basic needs of their family. With an initial capital of P1,000.00, she started selling her fish from their home. She was able to sustained the business and now she is earning an average net income of not less than P1,000.00 a month in which it contributes to their  family income. She is a new member to the co-op, and has been approved for a loan in the amount of P5,000.00. The loan will be used to buy additional fishing nets and other fishing materials. She is much thankful to PAGLAUM for the trust and the help extended to small entrepreneurs like her.

loans.use: Purchasing additional fishing nets and fishing materials

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a 32 year-old married mother of two children. She runs a retail shop called Kisekini Shop in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. She sells household goods and has been in this business for four years. She also earns extra income from small-scale farming. She is requesting a loan for Kes. 30,000 to purchase supplies of sugar, wheat flour, and cooking fat. In the future, she hopes to expand her shop into wholesale and employ people both in her business and in her home. She describes herself as hardworking.

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To purchase stock of sugar, wheat flour, and cooking fat.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more stock of shoes.

loans.name: Emilienne

texts.fr: H. Emilienne est née en 1984 à Abomey, dans le Département du Zou. Emilienne est mariée à AVAHOUN Borice, un chauffeur. Le couple a deux enfants et la famille vit à Agbodjèdo à Cotonou, Capitale économique du Bénin. Emilienne et son mari assurent ensemble les charges de la famille. C'est les sous-vêtements et les chaussures que Emilienne vend de façon ambulante à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. Pour mieux développer son activité, Emilienne sollicite un prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Emilienne H. was born in 1984 in Abomey, in the county of Zou. Emilienne is married to Borice AVAHOUN, a driver. The couple has two children and the family lives in Agbodjèdo in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Emilienne and her husband provide together for the family’s expenses.

Emilienne sells underwear and shoes as a traveling saleswoman in Dantokpa, the large international market of Bénin. To better develop her business, Emilienne is requesting a loan from ALIDé.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of shoes and underwear.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock of slippers and sandals.

loans.name: Zahera Group

texts.en:
This is the Zahera loan group. This group has two members, Zahera and Aziza, and Zahera is the group leader. 

Zahera lives with seven family members.She wants a loan for her husband who has a general store. Zahera's husband wants to buy all the things he needs for his general store. The store is the only source of income for Zahera's family of seven. Aziza wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for her tailoring business.

Zahera and Aziza thank AFS and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase gumboots and other shoes to sell

loans.name: Elgina

texts.en:
In the highlands of Tangub City, specifically in Purok 7 Silangit, is the residence of Mrs. Elgina M.. She is 37 years of age and is married to Mr. Elizer M.. They have five children who are now in their elementary and high school grades. Her husband is a carpenter with an average income per day of P300 which is just enough for the food needs of their family.

To help her husband, Elgina decided to engage in a banana buy and sell business. For two years already, with an initial capital of only P500, she was able to sustain her business and is able to earn an average income of not less than P2,500 a month. This is of great help to her family for their other needs, especially their children’s education.

As a new member of the PDP-LP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) Program of Paglaum MPC, she was given the privilege of obtaining her second loan of P8,000. She will use this to add to the capital in her existing banana buy and sell business and also for the down payment on a motorcycle to be used in the delivery of her goods.

The future income from this loan will be used for their daily needs, for repayment of the loan and for some house improvements.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her banana business and for a down payment on a motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more stock and rent a business premise.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 32 years old and married with three children. She describes herself as hardworking. She lives and works in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. She has run a retail shop called Mama JJ, selling household goods, for four years. She previously had a business buying and selling used clothes and currently supplements her income with some small-scale farming. 

She is requesting a loan for Kes. 30,000 to buy sugar, wheat flour, and cooking fat for her shop. Catherine hopes to expand her shop into wholesale and hire many employees as her business expands. 

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy food items for her shop.

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en:
Abdallah is a young single Palestinian man, living in the Al-shiekh Radwan neigbourhood of Gaza City.

Abdullah works in the morning in the Palestinian National Authority and he also own a mobile phone shop where he sells mobile phones, mobile accessories, phone cards and phone SIM cards (a SIM card or Subscriber Identity Module is a portable memory chip used in some models of cellular telephones).

Abdallah wants this loan to purchase new mobile phones to show them at his shop. He appears in the photo at his store.

loans.use: To purchase new mobile phones for his shop

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne is 43 years old and married with a 12-year-old daughter named Tracey. She has been running a grocery store for two years.
